body: Any thoughts on above request to add @Generated annotation for Groovy generated get/set methods for private variables?

my suggestion: make a JMH based microbenchmark in which you compare two empty lists. One time with the old implementation and one time with the new implementation. This benchmark can be done fully in Java and just copy&paste the methods in. This benchmark should hit the annotation path every time. And for comparison I would also add different sized lists (1, 10, 100, 1000, 1000000)... for example a List of Integer. They can both have the same content, just should not be the same reference. That would then also give an idea of the overhead in relation to the number of elements (which will be decreasing of course)
Not sure to understand with the length of the list should have an impact on the annotation overhead.  That cost it's constant, isn't it?

OK, I've some numbers. I've made a poor man currentTimeMillis delta for different iterations and using a CompileStatic annotation. 

The results are these: 

**iteration**|**w/o annotation (ms)**|**with annotation (ms)**|**delta (ms)**| overhead 
:-----:|:-----:|:-----:|:-----:|:-----:
10|239|264|25|10.46%
100|206|216|10|4.85%
1000|339|365|26|7.67%
10000|1430|1509|79|5.52%
100000|11370|11434|64|0.56%

The source code is [here](https://github.com/pditommaso/groovy/tree/annotation-benchmark/src/main/benchmark). The launcher script is [this](https://github.com/pditommaso/groovy/blob/annotation-benchmark/benchmark.sh). It was compiled and executed once in the master branch and then in the proposed change branch. 

Thoughts?

that cost is constant yes I know. But that constant cost has to be seen in comparison with actual lists. But it is not the benchmark I would like to see actually. You did something for toString(), not for compare. Also you did not do a warmup, which is why I suggested using jmh

I've never used jmh, but I can try to implement the benchmark with it if required. 

> You did something for toString()

Not really, I've just copy&pasted the same code in the `InvokerHelper.formatCollection` method (adjusting the missing constants/methods to equivalent ones)
I think you misunderstood me a bit. toString is not a real problem. The performance of equals is though. That is why we need a benchmark for that

üëç

Testing 2 empty lists is not enough. We should test lists with arbitrary objects, as otherwise the VM will perform optimistic branch optimizations.
I would not count on that optimization anymore with the reflective call in there

Indeed. I'm starting to become e bit skeptic about this proposal. Surely it will add some overhead and since this is a critical code I agree that it should be avoid as much at possible. 

For this reason I was thinking about a possible alternative. What about instead to make the default toString and equals strategy configurable via service loader (or even a system property). This would have several benefits: 

1) no extra reflective overhead 
2) no need for a new annotation in the groovy code
3) user provided strategy could rely on more performant implementation eg (use of marker interface instead of annotation) 
4) would be easier to remove in a future groovy release if this feature would be implemented/handled at core level as a language feature. 

What do you think about that?
...an alternative fix would be to change the ranges' `from` values to `0`
Merged. Thanks!
Thanks John for the fix and Daniel for merging. I moved the relevant example into a test - so it should remain working from now on. Thanks again!
Looks easy enough.

Some progress here, I've made a JHM benchmark using the current groovy master. The benchmark class is [this](https://github.com/pditommaso/groovy/blob/d37d1ae3f5b5b4e63c658378fce3153b1794565f/subprojects/performance/src/jmh/java/org/apache/groovy/bench/ListBench.java), comparing default groovy equals, one using the proposed annotation and another using a marker interface (all changes here https://github.com/pditommaso/groovy/commit/d37d1ae3f5b5b4e63c658378fce3153b1794565f).

These are the results:

not sure to understand how to read it.

According to the C√©dric's comment on this issue, `instanceof` is a special case. If the decision is to support it based on the type assigned then the docs may need some updating as well.

http://docs.groovy-lang.org/next/html/documentation/core-semantics.html#type-inference

> At compile time, we can‚Äôt make any guarantee about the type of a field. Any thread can access any field at any time and between the moment a field is assigned a variable of some type in a method and the time is is used the line after, another thread may have changed the contents of the field. This is not the case for local variables: we know if they "escape" or not, so we can make sure that the type of a variable is constant (or not) over time. Note that even if a field is final, the JVM makes no guarantee about it, so the type checker doesn‚Äôt behave differently if a field is final or not.

/cc @melix @paulk-asert

Yes, the pre-existing behavior is by design. While I think there are interesting discussions to be had about the intuitiveness of either alternative behavior, I think the existing behavior is the more conservative for similar reasons to why Java didn't allow var for fields/method types:
https://blog.codefx.org/java/java-10-var-type-inference/#Why-Can8217t-Field-And-Method-Types-Be-Inferred
I would certainly expect such a change to be discussed on the mailing list and a [VOTE][LAZY] if needed,
OK. I will revert it for the time being.

Agreed. Type inference is the hardest thing in the type checker, because every decision we make has to be carefully discussed. As Paul said, the reasons we don't do type inference on fields is the same reason why `var` isn't allowed on fields for Java (which makes me think we made a good decision because those people are way smarter than I am).

Yep. Type inference is really hard. Fixing some issues may break existing test cases easily... so some of them even cost my hours... but type inference is quite useful and interesting üòâ

P.S. I have reverted the PR
@danielsun1106 If you need reviews from me, especially "within 72h", please make sure to mention me on GitHub, I get a ton of emails from JIRA, there's almost no chance I notice a mention there.

@melix OK. I will mention you in time.
BTW, I wonder why we don't treat all `GString` as ` String`. For me, `GString` is just an internal class of Groovy, I never use its API. In addition, as we all know, `String` is widely used in Java world, so I believe few user is willing to use `GString` but just treat `GString` as a powerful version of `String`.

If `GString` had been implemented _eager_, it could have been transparent to the user, and never exposed as a public API. But that's not how it is, so we cannot treat it as such. Let me give examples:

```
def map = [:]
map[123] = "Hello $world"
```

then pass it to Java code. What should it see in the map ? A `String` ? A `GString` ? If it's a string, then it needs to be coerced as soon as it is put into the map. If it's a GString, then you're exposing it as a public API, and it means that it needs not to be coerced when you get it from the map. If so, why would you coerce the key but not the value? What if I write this:

```
def map = [:]
map[123] = "some $thing"
println(map[123].strings) // 1
def x = map[123] // 2
String x = map[123] // 3
GString x = map[123] // 4
```
1 should always work, because what we have put in the map is a GString, so we shouldn't coerce.
2 should also return a GString
3 uses explicit coercion, so you're asking for the evaluation of the GString
4 is explicitly typed, and nothing happens

It's all valid scenarios. So handling coercion for methods is one thing (coerce to a String when you have a method that takes a String), but handling them as a single object everywhere is another. This issue is about handling the coercion of a special "hidden" method call (`getAt(String)`) and is as such a bit special, I agree, but it doesn't mean we can do coercion everywhere.

@melix `"Hello $world"` seems to be evaluated eagerly. As `world` is not defined, error occurred.
```groovy
def map = [:]
map[123] = "Hello $world"
```

```
groovy.lang.MissingPropertyException: No such property: world for class: ConsoleScript3
```

as there is some confusion about the eagerness of GString:
* the referenced variables are bound eager
* toString on GString evaluates the GString, this includes toString for the values
In this example: 
```groovy
def x = 1
def gstring = "$x"
assert gstring == "1"
x = 2
assert gstring == "1"
```
we can see that gstring is bound to what is referenced by x. It seems like a complete eager evaluation, but that is hidden by the fact that x is not mutated here:
```groovy
class X {
  int i = 0
  String toString(){Integer.toString(i++)}
}
def x = new X()
def gstring = "$x"
assert gstring == "0"
assert gstring == "1"
```
as can be seen here, each conversion to String will reevaluate the GString and since the toString of X is for every call different, the GString will be evaluated to a different String each time.
also I should add that I think now that most users actually would want to have the eager variant

@danielsun1106 of course it fails, I didn't expect you to _run_ the code, it was an illustration that `GString` and `String` are different. It doesn't matter if it's eagerly evaluated or not in the examples, what matters is that they are different objects.
Proposed PR merged

Merged. I took 3 of the 4 commits. I reworked the groovy.util.CliBuilder to delegate to the commons-cli version. It seems better not to pollute the picocli version for the sake of providing functionality to the groovy.util version which we are possibly going to delete in 2.6/3. I think most people are going to see that the groovy,util version is deprecated and try to move off it quickly anyway.
+1, John, let me know if you'll get a chance to commit in the next day. If not, I'll merge before producing the rc-3 candidate.
Thank you both for the review.
@danielsun1106  you have to consider the story behind it, and that is reusable templates. But I can repeat mysefl "I think now that most users actually would want to have the eager variant"
See also https://github.com/remkop/picocli/releases/tag/v3.0.1 for more details.
